Social media platforms need to be ready on Election Day with policies along these lines, and clearly and transparently communicate how these policies will be enforced. Our democracy is counting on it.

(3) Content Delegitimizing the Election. Content that baselessly delegitimizes the election‚Äîcontent designed to sow doubt and division‚Äîshould not be amplified by the algorithms used on social media platforms.

(2) Voter Protection Preclearance. Just as live network TV institutes a short delay to prevent unacceptable content from airing, social media platforms can institute a short delay on content from specific high-reach accounts to allow for human review (h/t @accountabletech)

(1) Viral Circuit Breakers. Too often on social media, lies spread faster than the truth. A viral circuit breaker would slow the spread of viral content about the election until content moderators can conduct an effective review for accuracy.

This new report from @amprog offers up some common-sense ideas for how: https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/technology-policy/reports/2020/10/23/492232/results-not-found-addressing-social-medias-threat-democratic-legitimacy-public-safety-election-day

I remain committed to doing everything in my power to ensuring every Black woman has equal access to quality maternal healthcare.

CC: @RepUnderwood, @RepRobinKelly, @SenKamalaHarris

This pandemic has only heightened this crisis affecting Black women, especially in Alabama, which has some of the highest rates of maternal mortality in the nation. To put it in perspective: Black women are up to 3 times as likely to die in childbirth than white women.

As a member of the Black Maternal Health Caucus, I am urgently renewing my call to pass the Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act, a bill that would make critically important investments to support our families, moms and babies.

https://sewell.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/black-maternal-health-caucus-introduces-legislative-package-fight

We cannot let Dr. Chaniece Wallace's death be in vain. Pre-eclampsia is thought to be one of the most preventable pregnancy complications, but rates are higher, and the prognosis worse, among Black women. We must make childbirth SAFE for Black women!

Sending my deepest thoughts and prayers to the family of Dr. Chaniece Wallace. Wallace touched the lives of so many across Alabama. She was an Alabama native and a graduate of UAB School of Medicine. This is devastating news.

https://www.insider.com/dr-chaniece-wallace-died-in-childbirth-black-women-maternal-mortality-2020-10

H.R. 6930, MADE in America Act. This bill requires HHS to submit a report to Congress on barriers to domestic manufacturing of medical products.
H.R. 6877, The bill requires HHS to issue a report to Congress on all State, local, Tribal, and territorial requests for supplies from the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS) related to COVID-19.

H.R. 3927, the PDMP Help Patients Act. This bill authorizes HHS to create a pilot program to test the feasibility and outcomes of integrating a substance use disorder and behavioral health treatment locator tool into the prescription drug monitoring programs of eligible States.

H.R. 3878, the Block, Report, and Suspend Suspicious Shipments Act. This bill seeks to amend the Controlled Substances Act to require drug manufacturers, distributors and other DEA registrants to both report and stop any suspicious drug orders.

H.R. 7574, the Strengthening America's Strategic National Stockpile Act. This bill looks to spur domestic manufacturing and strengthen the national stockpile maintained by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to respond to public health emergencies.
